Hearing.Directory: <table-of-content>CONTENTS</table-of-content> <witnesses>WITNESSES</witnesses> <Witness>Hon Elaine L Chao</Witness> <peopleinfo>Secretary of Transportation US Department of Transportation: Testimony Prepared statement Responses to questions for the record from the following Representatives: Hon Bill Shuster of Pennsylvania Hon Mark Sanford of South Carolina Hon Jeff Denham of California PREPARED STATEMENTS SUBMITTED BY MEMBERS OF CONGRESS Hon Peter A DeFazio of Oregon Hon Grace F Napolitano of California</peopleinfo> <submittedMaterial>SUBMISSIONS FOR THE RECORD</submittedMaterial> <SubmittedMaterial>Oped of June</SubmittedMaterial> <peopleinfo>``President Trump's Right Privatize Air Traffic Control'' USA Today</peopleinfo> <SubmittedMaterial>Hon Elaine L Chao</SubmittedMaterial> <peopleinfo>Secretary of Transportation US Department of Transportation posthearing supplements to remarks</peopleinfo> <SubmittedMaterial>Letter of June</SubmittedMaterial> <peopleinfo>from Marc Rotenberg President</peopleinfo> <Doc-title>BUILDING A 21ST-CENTURY INFRASTRUCTURE FOR AMERICA: FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION AUTHORIZATION</Doc-title> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="">Washington, DC.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker=""> The committee met, pursuant to notice, at 9:35 a.m. in room 2167, Rayburn House Office Building, Hon. Bill Shuster (Chairman of the committee) presiding. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> The committee will come to order and I now recognize Mr. LoBiondo for a motion. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LoBiondo</speaker> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo"> Pursuant to rule 1(a)(1) of the rules of the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, I move that the chairman be authorized to declare recess during today's hearing. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Shuster">The question is on the motion.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Shuster">All those in favor, signify by saying aye.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Shuster">All those opposed, signify by saying nay.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Shuster">In the opinion of the Chair, the ayes have it, and the motion is agreed to.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Shuster">Well, I want to welcome everybody to today's hearing on FAA [Federal Aviation Administration] reauthorization and reform. I want to welcome Secretary Chao.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Shuster">Thank you very much for being here. This is your first hearing before the committee. And I know that you have a hard stop today at 11:30 because you have a meeting down at the White House. I know that the President has a number of stakeholders in continuing--talking about infrastructure to the stakeholders and to the American people. So we will do our best to abide by that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Shuster">Given those constraints, after consultation with the ranking member, we will observe the following timing: opening statement by the chairman and ranking member will be 3 minutes; questions for the chairman and ranking member will be 5 minutes. However, I will defer my questions until the end. And questions for Members will be 4 minutes, to ensure everyone gets a chance to ask questions today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Shuster">We could not be discussing a more important aspect of our Nation's infrastructure this morning. A long-term, comprehensive FAA authorization and reform bill is critical to bringing our infrastructure into the 21st century.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Shuster">We have held a number of hearings this year to prepare for an FAA bill, and getting your input about the administration's priorities is another critical step in that process.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Shuster">On Monday some of my colleagues and I joined you as the President announced his support and principles for air traffic control reform. As you know, this reform is vital to the future of our aviation system. But our FAA bill will address many much-needed reforms of the agency.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Shuster">We need certification reform, so that our manufacturers can compete on the world stage. We need to ensure we don't stymie innovation in new and emerging aviation sectors like drones and commercial space travel. We need to improve our airport infrastructure across the country. We need to ensure the safety of the system and the fair treatment of the flying public.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Shuster">Without bold action, America will, without a doubt, fall behind other nations in aviation. It is time for this committee and for Congress to act, and I look forward to working with you as we do that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> I would now like to recognize subcommittee chairman Mr. Larsen for 3 minutes to make an opening statement. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Larsen</speaker> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Larsen"> Ranking Member. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> Ranking Member Larsen; sorry about that. Three minutes? For an opening. I am confusing myself. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Larsen</speaker> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Larsen">First--thank you, Mr. Chairman. First off, I regret Mr. DeFazio is unable to attend today with a very important hearing with Secretary Chao. He is in Oregon, undergoing an urgent medical procedure. I fully expect him to be back to work and on the road to recovery next week. So I just want to pass that on.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Larsen">And, Mr. Chairman, thank you for calling this hearing today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Larsen">To Secretary Chao, we welcome you to the committee for your first hearing--at least first hearing with us.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Larsen">Yesterday Ranking Member DeFazio and I were joined by every Democratic member of this committee in introducing H.R. 2800, the Aviation Funding Stability Act, which offers simple and narrowly tailored solutions to the challenges facing the air traffic control system. The bill provides a steady funding stream for aviation programs, improves FAA's procurement and personnel systems, and amplifies the aviation stakeholder's voice in FAA management through the Management Advisory Council.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Larsen">Our bill fixes every problem identified by aviation system stakeholders, and does not engage in the science experiment of air traffic control privatization, which will slow down, rather than speed up, NextGen implementation. If we are going to have--if we have a discussion about air traffic control, we cannot deny the progress the FAA has made, and the motivation that this committee's oversight itself has provided.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Larsen">The FAA has rolled out DataComm in 56 of the busiest control towers, nationwide, and plans to deploy to en route facilities in 2021. Electronic flight strips, a symbol of all that is supposedly wrong with the current system, come online in 2020, as part of a larger suite of automation. And the FAA has published over 8,000 performance-based navigation procedures. The FAA has completed a network of automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast towers that will replace radar in 2020, and the list goes on.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Larsen">And a privatization bill will not come with a magic wand to accelerate these efforts. But the plan will not only freeze modernization programs in place, but also jeopardize enacting a long-term, comprehensive FAA reauthorization bill that the industry and flying public rightly demand.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Larsen">Yesterday, in a Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation Committee hearing on privatization, Republican Senator Jerry Moran said that ``With the administration's support for this proposal, the odds of getting a long-term authorization are diminished,'' adding, ``Those two things, the spinoff and the long-term authorization, may be mutually exclusive.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Larsen">In his closing remarks, Chairman Thune encouraged you, Secretary Chao, to find consensus among stakeholder communities because right now there are a whole lot of questions. An ever- growing list of stakeholders have registered objections.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Larsen"> And, Mr. Chairman, I just ask unanimous consent that the following items be entered today in the record, including public releases of aviation stakeholders and labor groups expressing concern about privatization. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Shuster">Without objection, so ordered.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> [The letter from the Electronic Privacy Information Center is on pages 66-70.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Larsen</speaker> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Larsen"> As well as the statement by Ranking Member DeFazio. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Shuster">Without objection, so ordered.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> [The written statement of Hon. Peter A. DeFazio is on pages 49-50.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Larsen</speaker> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Larsen">Federal unions, including PASS [Professional Aviation Safety Specialists], which represent FAA safety inspectors and technicians, also objected to privatization, as well as 100 mayors.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Larsen">Secretary Chao, you stated during your confirmation that you wanted a national consensus on air traffic control privatization. This plan has not attracted consensus in 20 years. There does not seem to be consensus. And we want to hear from you how you plan to go about doing that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Larsen"> So, with that, I want to thank you, Mr. Chairman, for holding today's hearing, and look forward to hearing from the witnesses. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> I thank the gentleman. And now I recognize the chairman of the subcommittee, Mr. LoBiondo, for a statement. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LoBiondo</speaker> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I think we have a tremendous challenge, but a tremendous opportunity with the reauthorization bill.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">In order to ensure that the United States remains at the forefront of aviation innovation, technology, and, most importantly safety, it is imperative that we pass a multiyear bill. Critical to the FAA's modernization effort is the cutting-edge research and development done by the outstanding men and women of the Federal Aviation Administration's Technical Center located in my district. This is the premier aviation research and development center, and I have the honor of representing them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">From pavement testing to lithium battery research, the work done at the tech center has developed and validated new technologies that have saved lives and makes our aviation system the safest in the world.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">Today, the unique labs at the tech center are focused on 21st-century challenges such as UAS [unmanned aircraft system] integration and cybersecurity efforts to protect the NAS [National Airspace System]. Our current construction of the Stockton Aviation Research and Technology Park, which is adjacent to the tech center, will complement those efforts, bringing private companies into direct and daily contact with the labs and the personnel at the tech center. I want to see their hard work better utilized and more efficiently integrated into our aviation system. But due to restrictions and decisions by FAA headquarters here in Washington, their efforts and expertise cannot and have not been fully leveraged.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">We hope to be able to change that. I look forward to the hearing today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">And, Secretary, thank you for being here.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo"> I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Mr. Shuster">I thank the gentleman, but now I would like to welcome our witness, Secretary Chao.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. Shuster">Again, your first time before the committee in this capacity.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Mr. Shuster">But I just want to remind all my colleagues that we have somebody here that has got a tremendous amount of experience in the transportation world. Not only has her family had a maritime shipping business, and still do, she was a Commissioner to the Federal Maritime Commission and also the Chair of that Commission, but also Deputy Secretary of Transportation under the first Bush administration and then Secretary of Labor under the second Bush administration. So we have someone here who is well versed on the issues, and well versed in Washington and its ways.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Mr. Shuster">But again, it is great to have you here today to testify.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Mr. Shuster">I ask unanimous consent that Secretary Chao's full statement be included in the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. Shuster">Without objection, so ordered.</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO, SECRETARY OF TRANSPORTATION,U.S. DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">Since your written testimony has been made part of the record, we would ask you to keep it down to 5 minutes. And, with that, Secretary Chao, please proceed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">U.S. DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">Secretary Chao. Thank you very much, Chairman Shuster, Ranking Member DeFazio, who is not here today, and all the members of the committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">Our air traffic control system is currently the best in the world. But it is under tremendous performance pressures that cry out for action. Despite spending billions of taxpayers' dollars over the past several decades, the Government has not been able to implement the state-of-the-art air traffic control technology that is needed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">Air traffic controllers, as mentioned, still use paper strips and 1960 technology. Congestion and delays cost more than $25 billion annually in higher fuel costs and lost productivity, not to mention degradation of our quality of life.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">By 2020, air passenger traffic will soar to over 1 billion annually. Air freight is expected to more than double over the next three decades. Drones and unmanned aircraft systems will have to be integrated into the national airspace. Without change, the current air traffic control system will be unable to keep up.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">So this administration has proposed to liberate the air traffic control operations and move it to a nonprofit, nongovernmental independent cooperative. The safety regulatory oversight function will remain at FAA. This will also solve a longstanding conflict of interest problem of an operating entity, the air traffic control system regulating its own safety.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">More than 50 countries worldwide currently have this structure. The proposed new air traffic control structure will ensure the deployment of state-of-the-art air traffic control technology that will manage the national airspace with more precision, thereby enhancing safety.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">Number two, it will protect our national security. It will maintain access for all users of the airspace, especially those in rural communities, general aviation, and the military. The new structure will also ensure financial self-sufficiency through retention of all user fees and access to the public markets.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">The new organization will be governed by a professional board of 13 directors nominated by all stakeholders, such as general aviation, airlines, airports, the general public, for example. No one stakeholder group will constitute a majority. The board will not be dominated by the airlines, as they will only have 2 out of the 13 seats.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">Currently, there is over $5 billion in the Aviation Trust Fund, which is not permitted to be spent. Under the new proposal, 100 percent of the surplus revenues would be reinvested back into the organization.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">Despite the fact that Congress allowed the FAA to adopt its own procurement rules in 2001, the system has been unable to deliver new air traffic control technology in a timely and cost-effective manner. And mindful that the key to any organization's success is its employees, the administration proposes that the new air traffic operations entity honor existing labor agreements.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">During the proposed 3-year transition, there will be no operational disruptions, as this proposed structure advocates a new governance and financing structure, not the physical movement of people nor equipment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO">We look forward to working with you, Mr. Chairman, the committee, and all stakeholders on these proposed reforms, because I know that we all want to ensure that the United States remains the world's leader in aviation, an industry that we pioneered.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="TESTIMONY OF HON. ELAINE L. CHAO"> Thank you very much, again. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Shuster">Again, thank you, Secretary Chao. And again, I am going to--because of the time constraints, again, we are going to go to the subcommittee chair and the ranking member for 5 minutes of questions. Everybody else will have 4 minutes. I am going to hold my questions until the end.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> So, with that, I recognize the subcommittee chair, Mr. LoBiondo, for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LoBiondo</speaker> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">Madam Secretary, can you explain how the research and development work at the technical center has helped to make our aviation system the safest in the world?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo"> Secretary Chao. You have given a wonderful introduction and description of what the center does, and I look forward, actually, to visiting it myself on August 4th. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LoBiondo</speaker> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">OK. Well, we will be able to fill you in with a lot more.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">I think, as you are aware, cybersecurity is an important issue for this committee. And I am assuming you are fully supportive of the efforts of the FAA Technical Center with cybersecurity and the advances they are making.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo"> Secretary Chao. Cybersecurity is very important, yes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LoBiondo</speaker> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">And the tech center employees are playing a key role in the safe integration of unmanned aircraft systems, both through their work at the tech center and through the test range that is there. Do you see us continuing to play a role in how the unmanned aircraft system will be integrated?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">The tech center--you may have been briefed on this--is taking the data from all six national test sites for the integration of unmanned aerial systems, and we would like to try to make sure that this will be a priority as we move forward for this integration.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo"> Secretary Chao. Drones and unmanned aircraft will be a part of the airspace in the future, which is why the administration is making this proposal. And certainly the center is very important in crafting the future of aviation. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LoBiondo</speaker> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. LoBiondo"> I yield back, Mr. Chairman. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Shuster">I thank the gentleman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Shuster">Madam Secretary, could you pull that microphone a little closer to you?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> Secretary Chao. Yes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Shuster">I think the whole thing moves.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> Secretary Chao. Better? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Shuster">The whole box moves forward, if you--yes. There you go, thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> Secretary Chao. Thank you. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> And with that I recognize Mr. Larsen for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Larsen</speaker> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Larsen">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Larsen">Secretary Chao, thanks for being here. I think this is the most exciting hearing of the day on Capitol Hill, by the way, so I just----</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Larsen">[Laughter.]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. Larsen"> Mr. Larsen [continuing]. For the record. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shuster</speaker> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. Shuster"> You can tell by all the cameras here. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Larsen</speaker> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. Larsen">That is right, all the attention.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. Larsen">So, as you are probably aware, you know, last year we had broad, bipartisan agreement on about 80 to 90 percent of the FAA reauthorization bill, and it got hung up on the debate we are having today on this issue. We are here a year later, nothing much has changed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Mr. Larsen">So I wanted to get your view on how the Department sees the future. Are you willing to support another extension if we can't get a whole bill done?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. Larsen">Or, as I hope, you know, we have got certification reform nearly done, we have got UAS integration of the airspace nearly done.
